awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Next Generation High School Chemistry Educational Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
The innovation is a novel teaching platform and related lesson plans that leverage touch-screen mobile computing devices and molecular modeling tools that will improve student comprehension of and interest in chemistry. Understanding the properties and three-dimensional (3D) structure of molecules is key to succeeding as a chemist; however, it is difficult to teach this to high school students using traditional media such as lectures, textbooks, and laboratory exercises. Students can have difficulty understanding how two-dimensional (2D) drawings used in textbooks represent the real 3D structures. Also, concepts such as chirality, molecular interactions, steric hindrance, and energetic stability are inaccessible without a 3D understanding of molecules. The proposal is to develop an electronic notebook, molecular visualizer, and interactive educational tool designed to increase student engagement, collaboration, and learning in high school chemistry. The software will run on touch-screen mobile devices, including mobile phones, making the technology accessible to a broad population. The combination of 3D molecular visualization, interactive lessons, annotated scenes, and traditional text, will make it much more intuitive to learn chemistry concepts that are traditionally considered difficult. 

The broader/commercial impact is a novel educational environment accessible by mobile devices, making it available to a wide audience of chemistry students both in the classroom and at home. The greatest immediate benefit will be to both high school and university students. Using currently accessible mobile devices, they will be able to visualize and manipulate molecules as never before in an intuitive and connected environment. This type of engagement will improve understanding of fundamental chemistry principles and will motivate more students to continue studying chemistry or other sciences, eventually increasing the number of Americans in scientific fields. The product of this proposal will be distributed to high school and college chemistry classrooms. In addition, personal versions will be available to individuals who want to further their educational experience or for home-schooling applications. Finally, the commercial value of this project becomes even more significant when considering potential extensions to other subjects, such as physics, biology, and chemical engineering. This application will also benefit researchers in the life sciences who frequently must visualize, manipulate, and share molecular models to make informed decisions.

por.por_cntn:
MolySym's goal was to develop a mobile application and sample lessons as a first step to innovating STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) education in the United States. Our mobile app, MyChemistry, and a set of introductory chemistry lessons will be available for free on the Apple App Store in 2014. The app uses powerful 3D molecular visualization software to allow chemistry students to interact with and learn about molecular interactions in a fun and intuitive way. Chemistry teachers can create their own lessons and media to share with their students via MyChemistry. In addition to meeting the goal for the award period, MolySym created a prototype of the authoring tool teachers will need to create and edit lessons. This tool is web-based and intuitive.

Chemistry is a core requirement for many STEM fields of study, yet students struggle to understand complex concepts and visualize the unseen world of molecules. Research has shown that students can mis-interpret 2D molecular representations and form incorrect mental images. These mistakes can make chemistry difficult and discourage the student. Other studies have shown that students who learn chemistry using 3D molecular visualizations understand the information better. MyChemistry's interactive 3D graphics will, therefore, help students understand chemistry, giving them the confidence to pursue STEM in college and in the workforce.

New educational standards are encouraging the use of technology in the classroom all around the country. Our platform will make it easy for teachers to incorporate technology use into their lectures and use touchscreen mobile devices students already have. Beyond this award period, MolySym will work on making MyChemistry able to run on all common devices and mobile operating systems. Additionally, the customizable nature of the lessons will appeal to educators who wish to tailor teaching materials to their students. Teachers will have the option to use pre-made lessons as-is or edit and create their own using MolySym’s web-based authoring tool. Teachers will easily connect with others through our web community, making it easy to network and share ideas to improve chemistry education.

Feedback about the demo created for Phase I from teachers and students was positive. The students really liked the interactive molecular graphics and thought materials like that would really clear up difficult concepts. They were excited about having options like MyChemistry available to them as study aides or classroom material. Teachers are excited about having an easy platform to use to make their own lessons, use technology in the classroom, and improve student learning.

MolySym's focus is on chemistry education now, but the MyChemistry platform will be transferrable to other subjects, both STEM and otherwise. Our product will give teachers the freedom to have total control over their lessons and will be more cost effective than replacing outdated textbooks. Beyond education, MyChemistry can be used in industry driven by chemistry and molecular biology innovations. Companies can develop their own training materials to better educate their employees and the public about their work.
